channel.title: I Do Not know what this means
channel.description:
public int getLastLogin(Client c) {
What does the (Client c) mean?

item.title: I Do Not know what this means
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

The function getLastLogin takes a parameter of the Client class. As RandQm said, you can call public methods from the Client object inside of that method now. This is called referencing an object.

You pass a reference to an object into the method so you can use the data/methods/etc. from that object. “c” is the name you would refer to the object as when you’re inside of the method.

Read full topic
item.source: I Do Not know what this means

item.title: I Do Not know what this means
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“RandQm, post:2, topic:526560”]It refers to your Client object.
Code going from the client object can be called inside the method now.
That why you see c. before some code.
But you could put Client dlzefnguaenguer if you would want, you just would have to put that row before any code
you want to call from the Client object.
So for organization they put c or client lowercase[/quote]

Oh thanks

Read full topic
item.source: I Do Not know what this means

item.title: I Do Not know what this means
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

It refers to your Client object.
Code going from the client object can be called inside the method now.
That why you see c. before some code.
But you could put Client dlzefnguaenguer if you would want, you just would have to put that row before any code
you want to call from the Client object.
So for organization they put c or client lowercase
